page.title: List of railway stations in Taiwan

revisions.rev:
Recently there are four railway operating companies in Taiwan: :{|class=wikitable !No.!!Logo!!Name!!Abbr.!!Service type!!Year opened!!No. of stations |-align=center |'''1'''||[[File:TRA Logo.svg|x30px]]||[[Taiwan Railway Administration]]||TRA||[[Inter-city rail]], [[Commuter rail]]||1891||217 |-align=center |'''2'''|| ||[[Taiwan High Speed Rail]]||THSR||[[Inter-city rail]], [[High-speed rail]]||2007||8 |-align=center |'''3'''||[[File:Kaohsiung Metro Logo(Logo Only).svg|x30px]]||[[Kaohsiung Mass Rapid Transit]]||KMRT||[[Rapid transit]]||2008||36 |-align=center |'''4'''||||[[Taipei Metro]]||TRTS||[[Rapid transit]]||1996||89 |} Some of the THSR are [[union stations]] with the TRA in the same name, some are in different names, and some even in different places with the TRA. So the THSR stations are called "''THSR XX Station''" to separate from the stations of TRA. The Taipei Metro and the Kaohsiung MRT are the urban metro in [[Taipei]] and [[Kaohsiung]] metropolitan area. The Taipei Metro opened on March 1996, the Kaohsiung MRT on March 2008. == [[Taiwan Railway Administration]] == The station names of the [[Taiwan Railway Administration]] are romanized in [[Hanyu Pinyin]] since 2008, but some major stations named after the counties and major cities remain their traditional spelling, e.g., Keelung and Kaohsiung. In the history, the names are in [[WadeâGiles]] system before 2002, and in [[Tongyong Pinyin]] from 2002 to 2008. {{compactTOC5T}}
